title: Dean Lonergan
text:
Dean Robert Lonergan is a New Zealand former professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer, and current events promoter. He is the promoter of <a href="Jeff%20Horn">Jeff "The Hornet" Horn</a> who won the <a href="World%20Boxing%20Organization">WBO</a> Welterweight World Championship against <a href="Manny%20Pacquiao">Manny Pacquiao</a> in 2017. He was one of the co promoters for <a href="David%20Tua%20vs%20Shane%20Cameron">David Tua vs Shane Cameron</a>.
Playing career.
Lonergan represented the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand national rugby league team</a> from 1986 to 1991 and also represented <a href="Auckland%20rugby%20league%20team">Auckland</a>. He played for the <a href="Glenora%20Bears">Glenora Bears</a> and <a href="City%20Newton%20Dragons">City Newton Dragons</a> in the <a href="Auckland%20Rugby%20League">Auckland Rugby League</a> competition and the <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra Raiders</a> in the <a href="NSWRL%20Premiership">NSWRL Premiership</a>. He spent 1989 with the <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a> in England.
In a Test match against Australia in Melbourne in 1991, Lonergan clashed famously with Kangaroo forward <a href="Steve%20Roach%20%28rugby%20league%29">Steve Roach</a> and had to be carried from the field. However he returned to the field and New Zealand won the match.
Warriors.
Lonergan was a board member of the <a href="Auckland%20Warriors">Auckland Warriors</a> from 1996 until 1997.
Personal life.
Lonergan was educated at <a href="Massey%20High%20School">Massey High School</a> and was part of the breakfast show on <a href="LiveSPORT">LiveSPORT</a> radio. He was also a columnist for "<a href="The%20New%20Zealand%20Herald">The New Zealand Herald</a>". He is the owner of Dean Lonergan Events Ltd and the promoter of the <a href="Fight%20for%20Life%20%28New%20Zealand%20charity%29">Fight for Life</a> charity <a href="boxing">boxing</a> events. Following the resignation of <a href="Robert%20Muldoon">Robert Muldoon</a>, Lonergan stood in the <a href="Tamaki%20by-election%2C%201992">1992 Tamaki by-election</a> for a seat in the <a href="43rd%20New%20Zealand%20Parliament">43rd New Zealand Parliament</a>, as a stunt for <a href="Radio%20Hauraki">Radio Hauraki</a>. Of 14 candidates, he came sixth with 0.60% of the votes. Dean Lonergan now runs D&L Events along with his son Liam Lonergan.
Honours.
In the <a href="2012%20Birthday%20Honours%20%28New%20Zealand%29">2012 Queen's Birthday and Diamond Jubilee Honours</a>, Lonergan was appointed a <a href="New%20Zealand%20Order%20of%20Merit">Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit</a> for services to sport and philanthropy.
